‚òëÔ∏èKey Support for Rural Hospitals: ACA significantly reduced uncompensated care costs. As hospitals face an influx in coronavirus patients, it is critical that they are paid for the treatment they provide.

‚òëÔ∏èMedicaid Expansion: Because of ACA, states can get additional funding to expand Medicaid to vulnerable populations. 17 million+ have coverage through Medicaid expansion. Importantly, Medicaid‚Äôs funding structure allows funds to increase in response to emergency like COVID
‚òëÔ∏èIncreased CDC Funding: The Affordable Care Act established the CDC Prevention and Public Health Fund, which helps states prepare for disease outbreaks.

‚òëÔ∏è Coverage for 20+ Million People: Because of the ACA, more than 20 million Americans gained health coverage. People with insurance are much more likely to see a doctor when they are sick and to get the treatment they need.

‚òëÔ∏èProtections for as Many as 133 Million Americans With Preexisting Conditions: Under the ACA, insurance companies are not allowed to discriminate against those with preexisting conditions by denying them coverage or charging higher rates.

‚òëÔ∏èAccess to Vaccinations Without Cost Sharing: Once a COVID vaccine is developed, the ACA would cover it without cost-sharing, because it requires plans to cover all vaccinations recommended by the CDC‚Äôs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP).

‚òëÔ∏èComprehensive Coverage: The ACA established what are known as ‚Äúessential health benefits,‚Äù such as prescription drugs and hospitalization. Coronavirus testing and treatment are essential health benefits and must be covered by all ACA-compliant plans.

Americans are relying on our health care system now more than ever before as about 27 million lost their employer-provided insurance because of the COVID19 outbreak by May, and the ACA is one of our most critical tools to protect Americans from the consequences of the virus.
